bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, September 8, 1952

div1.p: Hench informs Nogueira that the U.S. State Department and the Surgeon General's Office would like to receive an official invitation in order to send a representative to the dedication of Camp Lazear. There remain only two survivors from the experiments: Hanberry and Cooke.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, September 8, 1952
div1.opener:
September 8, 1952
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Habana, Cuba
My dear Pedro:
div1.p:
As I told you in my letter of August 12 that I would do, I followed up
the suggestion mentioned in paragraph 6 of your letter of August 6 and
have obtained informally, the attitude of the Surgeon General's Depart-
ment, U. S. Army, concerning the dedication of Camp Lazear. I have re-
ceived a personal and also a semi-official reply from Major General
George E. Armstrong, the Surgeon General. I enclose a copy of General
Armstrong's letter of August 22. I have also heard from General Love
and others in Washington. They are all delighted to know of the plans
which you and your colleagues have been formulating. They are all
greatly interested in the dedication of Camp Lazear and in his personal
letter to me, General Armstrong expressed the hope that he might himself
be able to visit Cuba for the dedication but since he did not know the
exact date and since he was going to be away from time to time, he was
going to suggest the possibility that Major General Paul H. Streit,
Commanding General of Walter Reed Medical Center and of the Walter Reed
Army Hospital, would represent him if he himself could not come.

Our mutual friends in Washington are certain that the State Department
would be delighted to receive official notification and an invitation to
have a representative at the dedication. May I state therefore that as
soon as your plans are sufficiently definite and when you know the date
for the dedication, that an invitation be sent to the State Department
and another one sent to the Surgeon General of the U. S. Army, either
directly to him in his official capacity or to him through the State
Department. Such an invitation will receive their anthusiastic attention.

May I ask you, Pedro, if you are more certain now as to the exact time
for the dedication? If you are planning to dedicate it the end of this month,
the time is getting short and if at all possible, the invitations from
the Cuban government should go out at their earliest convenience.

As I wrote you before, the only two survivors of the actual experiments
are Dr. Robert P. Cooke, Lexington, Virginia and Mr. James L. Hanberry
61 Summers Avenue, Orangeburg, South Carolina. I have not heard from
Doctor Cooke. When I wrote Mr. Hanberry some weeks ago telling him of
the preliminary plans, he expressed at once his hope that he might be in-
vited but I do not believe he could go to Cuba at his own expense.

I am sure that you will want to send invitations not only to Doctor Cooke
and Mr. Hanberry but also to the following:
General and Mrs. Walter L. Reed, 2810 Thirty-Sixth Place N.W., Washington D.C.
Mrs. Blossom Reed, Blue Ridge Summit, Pennsylvania
Mrs. Estela Agramonte Rodrigues Leon, Calle K, Vedado, Havana (Agramonte's
daughter)
Mr. and Mrs. Houston Lasear, P. O. Box 812, Santa Barbara, California (Lazear's son)
Mr. and Mrs. W. D. Briggs, 106 The Uplands, Berkeley, California (Lazear's daughter)
General and Mrs. Albert E. Truby, 145 Laurel Street, San Francisco, California
Mrs. J. R. Kean, 2804 N Street N.W., Georgetown, Washington, D. C.

May I say that all of these people would, I am sure, be delighted to have
official invitations to come to Cuba; however I do not believe any of this
latter group can come. At your suggestion, I wrote them informally telling
them of the tentative plans. Unfortunately, because of their physical in-
capacities or for other reasons, the following have stated specifically
that although they would be delighted indeed to receive an official invita-
tion, they do not believe they can come: General Reed, Blossom Reed, Mrs.
Briggs, Mrs. Kean, General Truby. I have not heard from Houston Lazear.

I assume that at the appropriate time you and your colleagues will contact
the American Embassy in Havana. Our Washington friends assure me that if
invited the American Embassy would be delighted indeed to participate or
have a representative present at the ceremony.

Since writing you previously about the exact names, I have not heard whether
you plan to use the full name or the first names and initials, nor have I
heard what names you finally decided upon. I enclose an actual copy of the
names as sent to me from the Surgeon General's Office. They consider this
the official spelling. However they have the middle name of Mr. Hanberry
spelled wrong. They have spelled it Lanard. In his own handwriting, Mr.
Hanberry signs his name James Leonard Hanberry.

Would you end your colleagues wish to send an official invitation to any
of the officers of the Walter Reed Memorial Association? They are as follows:

General Albert G. Love, 2709 Wisconsin Avenue N.W., Washington, D. C., is
now Secretary, and I will send you within a few days the names of the other
officers.

Is there anything further that I can do for you? I would appreciate an
answer to my letter of August 12.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Enclosures
P.S.: I think I have obtained for you a copy of Sternberg's 1890 book. Did
you receive the copy of Mrs. Sternberg's account of her husband's life which
I sent to you on August 12?
